title: Poor quality, poor taste, lots of clean up
body:
The concept is great:
- Combines grinder and brewer, taking less space,
- Makes single cup, which is good since I'm the only coffee drinker in my household,
- Relatively inexpensive.

However, after using it for just over 6 weeks, I have to recommend against buying this product. The design and construction are very shoddy. Here are a few reasons:
- The reusable filter cup has a little plastic latch that keeps it closed. That latch broke after a few weeks of use, such that it doesn't fully close anymore (see picture). It's still usable, but leads to more ground spill.
- The burr mill makes a mess, a lot of the grounds fall off to the side or below, even around the machine, requiring a regular cleaning.
- The burr mill got stuck after just a month of use; I cleaned it as the manual recommends, and it got stuck again the next day.
- The reusable filter is hard to clean. I shake it and hit it over the trash can and most grounds remain stuck there. I need to send a lot of water through at high pressure to get it empty, and then most of the grounds fall in my sink and it seems like a waste of water.
- The coffee quality is subpar when making 12 oz. The last 1-2 oz is just warm water.
- There is a side compartment to store the reusable filter cup. Since I am using the reusable filter cup every day, I leave it in the brew chamber until the next day, so I don't need that compartment. title: Well designed and attractive unit. Unfortunately the coffee tasted odd

Unfortunately, when I tried some test brews using my existing pre-ground coffee the coffee had an odd plasticky / metallic taste? I had followed the initial cleaning instructions / installed the rinsed * soaked filter as instructed and used the same coffee and water as I would in my old filter press.

I thought it was perhaps just my perception, so I ran a quick test using the filter press as a control.

I made 10 oz. cups using the same water and pre-ground coffee in the Bodum and the Cuisinart (I doubled the amounts for the Bodum as I don't usually just have 1 cup, but the ratios were the same).

I let the Bodum steep for about 4 minutes (as I usually do) and then turned on the Cuisinart.

Checked the temperature of the finished brews and they were within about 5 degrees (160-165F).

The result confirmed what I thought. The Cuisinart brew definitely had a plasticky / metallic aftertaste that was completely absent from the Bodum. This seems really odd to me given that the Cuisinart has the added feature of the activated carbon filter.

For all I know perhaps this is how coffee from units like this typically taste, since its the first I have ever owned. After all, the Bodum I use does not really have any plastic parts (its just glass and a stainless steel screen).

Although I really hate to return items, that is what I will likely do with this unit.

Pros: The unit is extremely well engineered, it looks great and works exactly as advertised ( I did not actually use the grinder though, so can't comment on that). It fits in a small space and is very reasonably priced.

Cons: The only one for me was the slight off-taste.

The grinder does drop a few grinds each grind, so I keep a finger bowl there to catch them and toss them into the next cup. I dont try to appear like I live in a magazine, so the look of this doesnt bother me.

title: Finally, a hybrid coffee maker that I am happy with
body:
Over the years I have tried making coffee with various K cup machines including other Cuisinarts with pods and grind your own k cup dispensers (e.g. Java Jig), grind and drip using a caraffe, conventional drip coffee with paper filter etc to find a flavor that I was looking for and that was effortless and fast for a household solo coffee drinker. Lets face it k cup coffee lacks flavor and freshness that you get from a of a drip type maker or or drip cafaffe with your own beans. Well the cuisinart single serve is the best compromise I have seen. Grinding beans is easy and quick (and quite quiet compared to my stand alone grinder) and the custom grind housing is easy to insert/remove and clean - something I find extremely useful. Putting the holder in and out for the custom grind or k cup canister is simple and both are easy to clean - something that has always bothered me with other dual purpose k cup/grind machine. It makes good coffee with a pod or custom grind although I prefer grinding my own. The features are barebones - no timers/extra strong blend/clock features etc which actually is an asset.
Ok so the negatives - the grinder is a bit messy leaving ground coffee on the drip tray (the carriage holder for the grinder could be a bit more snug), the water dispenser is low capacity which is okay because I never left water standing in my makers preferring cold filtered water but the design of the water well is such that you have to be careful as you pour in water or you will get a spash from the water hitting the back wall of the reservoir which juts out into the water fill area. In SUMMARY for a hybrid machine (grind and k cup) it provides a good cup of coffee using EITHER method, has a small footprint with a nice ergonomic, functional design and makes this coffee snob quite happy.

title: BEST Fresh Ground Bean to Cup Single Serve!
body:
I've tried them all, and this Cuisinart Single Serve Coffee Maker with a built-in grinder wins the day for a hot, delicious cup of fresh-ground coffee on demand. Pods? Why? Bags of pre-ground coffee? Why? Not when you can have fresh ground AND adjust the amount of grounds for each cup of coffee. My current daily beans are Counter Culture's Fast Forward, which is a washed, medium blend of African and South and Central American beans with nutty, sweet, and creamy notes. (For a slightly darker roast, I like Blue Bottle Giant Steps or Bella Donavon). I grind these an extra 2 seconds past the default grind and select the 8 oz cup option, which I dispense into a coffee cup containing a splash of pre-heated (35 seconds in the microwave) milk. Delicious! As good as or better than the daily coffee at any of the boutique coffee shops in my area. For a 10 oz cup, grind an additional 4-5 seconds past default, although I prefer the extraction of the 8 oz option. I've never tried grinding and brewing the 12-cup option.

PRO TIP: Go ahead and buy a couple of extra reusable filter cups for a quicker, more convenient second (or third) cup. Also, readying a just-used reusable filter cup is simple: just remove the filter basket from the grey cup, turn it upside down, and tap it firmly several times on a paper towel or paper plate to dislodge the caked, used grinds. A quick rinse of the basket and cup under the faucet, and you're ready to go again. I own a couple of fairly high-end grinders and a top-of-the-line electric drip coffee maker, as well as various pour-over and steeping brewers, but this little Cuisinart has replaced them as my daily coffee setup. Highly recommended.

title: Best when used with paper filters
body:
It took me a few days to find the best grind and brew experience. I'm not a fan of metal filters and prefer paper single cup filters for clean up and no slug in the bottom of my coffee cup. The canFly Compatible for K-Carafe 4-CUP Reusable Coffee Filter Premium Disposable Paper Filters (Unbleached 100) work great.

For me, I prefer to stop the grind with about 1/4 inch yet to fill (the grind button can be pushed to start and stop the grind as needed - so I let it grind for a bit, stop it, check it, then grind again until the cup has about 1/4 left to fill).

Another tip: after putting the paper filter into the metal filter, I only put the metal filter under the grinder (I don't put the metal filter into the gray plastic case).

After a few tries, I am now able to grind and brew a cup of coffee without any ground coffee on my countertop.

The first coffeemaker that came didn't work: it would turn on and I could grind beans, but the coffee sizes lights never lit up and didn't do anything. Sent it back for a return. The second coffeemaker did the same thing. I called Cuisinart and they said to unplug the device and leave the coffee pod insert lever completely up. I let it sit for an hour like that, then with the lever still up, I plugged it in and it started working as expected. No issues for the past few weeks.

The space to insert a cup in a bit small for me. Keurig has a generous space for different size mugs and travel mugs, but I can't fit my large Yeti, but it's not a deal breaker.

I also found that the 8oz, 10oz, and 12oz cup sizes were all off by 2oz. 8oz button = 10oz of coffee, etc. So my favorite coffee cups fill almost to the top when I push the 8oz button. Again, not a deal breaker, but a bit of a surprise. I prefer the 8oz amount as I like my coffee a bit on the strong side.

Having used various Keurig machines over the years, and the full-size coffee pot with a separate grinder, this machine is really an excellent solution for me. I usually only need one cup of coffee in the morning, so I can grind the beans, insert the filter in the pod, and brew a cup of coffee in about 2 minutes. The paper filter makes clean up quick and easy and I'm good to go.

Convenience: Grinding and brewing a hot cup of joe is easy and fast! No separate coffee grinder or mess required. It provides the convenience of a K-cup brewer without the modern guilt of creating landfill waste. If you happen to be short of beans, just remember that emergency stash of Costco K-cups you keep out-of-site from you lover and friends.

Need to Know: Buy extra reusable coffee filter cups. Yeah, yeah, yeah... You're buying more plastic... More angst! But you still take your own bags to the grocery store, don't you?! It's much easier to clean several of them together once coffee time is done, rather than while half awake after your first cup. But wash your cups before bedtime! You'll be pissed if you have to wash them at 6 AM in a pre-caffeine stupor.
Compatible cups are sold cheaply all over Amazon.

Tip for Stronger Coffee: After grinding, tap the filter cup on the cabinet a few times, put it back on the grinder, grind four seconds more, tap again and brew. Don't put so much coffee that you have to force the lid closed.

Small Gripes: The water reservoir is bit small. This would be an easy fix for Cuisinart on future generations of this product. The process is a bit messier that my old Keurig (but not bad).

title: Terrorized by the grinder
body: There are no controls on the grinder. I’ve been using this single cup maker about 2 months. I bought it because I thought it would be less messy than my mueller 10 cup pot and blade grinder. It is not! First you need paper filters to easily dispose of the grinds so they don’t clog up a garbage disposal. The only filters available are the tall (oversized) ones in the photo. The grinder leaves grinds on the back rim of the mesh filter whether you have a paper in it or not. There is a box below the steel rack that over time collects the grinds, as you see in the photo. You cannot lift the grinder to be able to slide out the filter after the coffee is ground into it so that the mountain of grounds doesn’t make a mess. You can see in the photo where it’s messy at the back rim and in the other photo where I tamped the grinds down with my finger. The grinder goes for about 18 or 19 seconds so this is what I do. I grind for a count of 4 or 5 elephants, then press the power on/off button. Then I slide out the filter cup and tamp down those grinds. And do that again. When you put the paper filter in you have to mush it in like a pie crust. Make sure the lip side that gathers the most paper is NOT sitting at the back end where you grind, and is not at the front end where you latch the plastic holder. If that plastic top gets cantankerous and won’t click shut just push down the machine lid. You need a paper filter unless you like a lot of sludge and don’t worry about coffee grinds clogging your house drainage.

title: Thin coffee and a waste of coffee beans
body:
I don't typically write product reviews, and hate leaving one like this. However, if you are looking for an all-in-one bean grinder and drip coffee maker that does one cup at a time, do NOT buy this product.

The same volume of beans are ground to fill the filter cup irrespective of how much, or how strong, you want your coffee. You cannot adjust the fineness / coarseness of the grind. Most grinds make it into the filter cup, but the process nevertheless leaves grinds all over your counter. Because the unit is also designed to accommodate single-serve coffee capsules (e.g., k-cups), the water is poured through your fresh grounds in a tight stream that quickly drills a hole through the grounds, such that there is no opportunity for steeping and half of your cup will be filled by near-clear water, not brewed coffee. And after all of that, the process still leaves a thick layer of silt at the bottom of each cup.

Bottom line: if you want a coffee maker that uses pre-packaged, single-serve pods, this might work. If you want a cup of coffee brewed with freshly ground beans, find another solution.

title: Very weak and watery coffee
body:
Very disappointed in the quality of the coffee. It is weak and watery. Even with brand new, high-quality, dark, oily beans, the coffee was weak, and that's on the 8 oz setting (which actually gives you about 10 oz of coffee). It's even more watery on the 10 and 12 oz settings.

I called Cuisinart for help, but they only had two suggestions: don't overfill the hopper so the beans can grind more easily, and buy fresh, dark beans. I'd already tried both of those things, so they were no help. Also, the customer support person didn't know anything about this machine and kept asking me which grind setting I was using. It took a bit of back and forth before I could convince them that there's only one, default setting. They then left me on hold for quite a while they read the manual.

Issues that create watery coffee:
--The machine only has one grind setting, which they claim is medium, but seems more coarse than medium to me. It's hard to get strong, flavorful coffee with coarse grounds.
--The water runs through the grounds too quickly, so the flavor doesn't have time to bloom and develop.

On the other hand, I love virtually everything else about this coffee maker, which is why I gave it 2 stars. If you prefer your coffee weak, you might love this machine.

Pros:
--Looks good
--Doesn't take up too much counter space
--Easy to use
--Very easy to clean
--Very convenient to have a grinder and a coffee maker in one product
--Good-sized bean hopper and water reservoir means you only have to refill occasionally, so it's fast and easy to make a cup of coffee.

The filter basket was tricky to find. There's a door in the side of the machine that holds it. Look closely because the door blends in and is hard to see.

Everything Kitchens did a great job shipping us the product. It came on time, was well packed, and they got back to me right away when I had a question.

1) the grinder spews coffee grinds on the counter when ever it grinds beans and overfills the basket so when you slide the basket out it spreads more grinds on the counter. Both of these issues could have been easily corrected during design if they would have better inclosed the grinder area and set the grind capacity just a little bit less.

Adding beans into the hopper is easy enough - but why not make the top a little wider instead of just barely able to squeeze some beans next to the grinder. Just a very easily avoidable design flaw IMO.

Unless you have a very small travel it doesn't even come close to fitting. I'm not talking about the monster Yeti ones or anything like that. I'm talking about the standard ones you buy in target or get a a trade show. the ones that are EVERYWHERE ... I have no idea how they thought that was a good design. Terrible, you basically have to brew in something else and then pour into your standard sized travel mug. Poor design.

I'm on the fence at this point. I hate the K cups as an everyday coffee which is what led me to this but it's a pretty big miss on some of the very very basic features.
